title: 107_s2194
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Arafat Accountability Act". It includes findings related to the accountability of Arafat. The "Arafat Accountability Act" finds that the PLO, led by Yasser Arafat, failed to uphold promises made in the Oslo Accords regarding peace, renunciation of terrorism, and maintaining law and order in the West Bank and Gaza. Arafat's lack of credible security guarantees has led to ongoing terrorism against Israeli and American civilians. Yasser Arafat has violated his commitment to peace by purchasing offensive weaponry from Iran, funding terrorists responsible for attacks in Israel, and failing to respond adequately to end homicide bombings, complicating the conflict resolution prospects in the region. The Sense of Congress is outlined in Section 3. The Sense of Congress outlined in Section 3 includes urging an immediate cessation of terrorist activities, surrender of Palestinian extremists to Israel, and concrete actions by Yasser Arafat and the PLO to condemn terrorism and dismantle terrorist infrastructures. The Congress supports efforts to end financial support for terrorism and urges Arab nations to stop funding terrorist operations and payments to families of terrorists. Congress also backs the President's work with Israel, Arab states, and the international community to achieve peace in the region. Congress also backs the President's work with Israel, Arab states, and the international community to achieve peace in the region. Sanctions will be imposed. The Secretary of State is prohibited from issuing visas to members of the Palestine Liberation Organization or Palestinian Authority. The President can waive this prohibition on a case-by-case basis for national security reasons. Measures will be taken to limit the activities of PLO offices in the United States. Travel restrictions will be imposed on senior PLO representatives at the United Nations. The Secretary of State, with the cooperation of the Attorney General, will identify and seize the assets of the Palestine Liberation Organization and the Palestinian Authority in the United States, as well as the personal assets of PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat in the United States. SEC. 5. REPORT ON PLO TERRORIST ACTIVITIES.

Within 30 days of enactment, the President must report to Congress on PLO terrorist acts every 90 days. The report will determine if the PLO should be designated as a terrorist organization.

SEC. 6. DURATION OF SANCTIONS.

Sanctions will continue until the President reports that conditions warranting them have ceased.

SEC. 7. APPROPRIATE CONGRESSIONAL COMMITTEES DEFINED. SEC. 7 defines "appropriate congressional committees" as specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives.
